He reports a giving-way sensation, instability, and weakness, rated 4-5/10 pain, worse with prolonged standing or sitting. He denies significant swelling, redness, clicking, or popping. His daily activity level is very low. My initial differential included osteoarthritis, meniscal tears, ligamentous injury, and even patellofemoral pain syndrome, but the normal imaging essentially rules those out. dialogue_history.speaker: Doctor
dialogue_history.text: Good morning/afternoon, Dr. [Otolaryngologist's Name]. Thank you for reviewing this case. We have a patient presenting with a two-month history of progressive hoarseness. Initially, I considered several differential diagnoses, including vocal cord nodules or polyps given the chronic nature of the hoarseness, especially in a patient with a long history of smoking (50 pack-years, quit 10 years ago). However, the patient also has a history of COPD, which I initially thought might be contributing to the cough and possibly indirectly to the hoarseness through chronic irritation. The fiberoptic laryngoscopy revealed white plaques on both vocal cords, and the biopsy confirmed the presence of hyperkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium and fungal hyphae, positive on Grocott-Gomori methenamine silver stain. This strongly suggests candidiasis (thrush) of the vocal cords. My questions for you, Dr. [Otolaryngologist'
